But our bouncer got sore,
Quickly showed them the door
As he said, "We don't serve breakfast here."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
It lives on cicadas and fills
Up its gut with the insects it kills.
Well, I can't be much blunter:
This wasp is a hunter—
Gets thrills from its bug-killing skills.

limerick_list.author: Taillefer
limerick_list.text:
The excreta that hit me (called fecula)
From above, on the Isle of Benbecula,
Were a nasty surprise,
And I do not surmise
They were heaven-sent. No, they were secular.

limerick_list.author: hugh t.
limerick_list.text:
As he comes to the end of life's road,
This old man has to creep like a toad;
But no pity he begs,
For he boasts that his legs
May be bloody, but still they're unbowed.

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
I have slaved; now I champ at the bit.
They'll be marking me soon — this is it.
I shall get it together,
All wrapped up in leather:
I'm ready to bind and submit.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
This insect, a hopeless romantic,
Is clownish and frequently frantic.
Wherever he goes
His grotesquery shows—
He's an ant, and he's overly antic.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
Though you shriek, "This rhyme is consonantal!"
Its vowels, you dimwit, dismantle
Your consonant claims!
Such inconsonant games
Will assist you no more than your rant'll!

limerick_list.author: Steve Ngai
limerick_list.text:
Said Berta, "I've got a confession:
Though you thought I devised the expression
For 'erythrocyte center,'
I'm not the inventor:
German Delle means 'dent' or 'depression.'"

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
Andrewsarchus, carnivorous beast,
Was the king of the Eocene feast.
But his fossils are rare,
So his profile is spare:
Like an ungulate wolf — now deceased.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Thanksgiving, I'm happy to hear,
Will fall on a Thursday this year.
It's been thus, as you know,
Many years in a row,
Although how that works out, I'm not clear.

limerick_list.author: DBRHoffman
limerick_list.text:
I hollered across the field, "Sucker!
You ride like a fat, drunken trucker!"
Then I spurred on old Tony
(My trustworthy pony)
And scored four more times in that chukker.

limerick_list.author: Aliza
limerick_list.text:
Is this structure a fence or a wall?
Both are flat, both divide, both are tall.
Look far down, Buttercup,
At what holds the thing up.
For a fence, no foundation at all.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Scattered body parts strewn here and there
Would have curled any normal man's hair.
But from one jaded cop,
Grisly humor, nonstop:
"I get paid by the piece, I don't care."

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Fraxinella: the gardening pros
Say this plant is unusual. It grows
In warm woodland soils
And exudes toxic oils
Which catch fire. (So stay armed with a hose!)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The Sarge screamed "AT EASE!" in my ear.
"You can do as you like.  IS THAT CLEAR?!"
While I'm not at attention,
I wish I could mention
I'm never at ease when he's near.

limerick_list.author: Ulfras
limerick_list.text:
In describing the origin of man,
Charles Darwin sincerely began
Sketching anthropogenesis.
If true science, then is his
Theory not part of God's Plan?

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
There are auditory nerves in our ears
That connect with the brain, it appears.
Neural impulses flow
Through them both—this is so
We can hear and not fall on our rears.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
In the twenties, Aunt Lulu loved dancing,
Short dresses, bobbed hair and romancing:
Life was sweet for this flapper.
Now, Lulu's a napper,
At peace now that time is advancing.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
See the skin, tossed away when unzipped,
Hit the floor, squashed by Ethel who slipped,
Landing flat on her back.
Watch the patients' cool crack:
They are going bananas; they've flipped!

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
Their car's broken down and they're weary;
The castle looks haunted and eerie.
In the dark, a door creaks,
And the audience shrieks:
"Can't you just turn the lights on there, deary?"

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
When my son broke the capitate bone
In his wrist, boy, oh, boy, did he moan!
It was not that it pained him,
But the cast that restrained him
Meant he couldn't play games on his phone.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
They don't fly, are not purple, but ate
Human beings, as Greek myths relate.
Anthropophagi raging
Need lifetimes of caging;
But Lecter escaped that harsh fate.

limerick_list.author: Giorgio Coniglio
limerick_list.text:
Cellphone-photo  attachment discrete,
Sent by friends on a yoga retreat
At a seaside resort:
Croaking toucans cavort.
Tropic birds with huge beaks who don't 'tweet'.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Some speak English, Armenian, Dutch,
Spanish, German, Norwegian, or such,
Each a glossonym: name
Of a language. Their aim:
To facilitate keeping in touch.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
My solicitor's subject to slumbrance,
So my property deal's in penumbrance.
To dispel clouds on title
In law, it is vital
To rid all the deeds of encumbrance.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
Some ciderkin's what we will make
From the leftover cider mash. Take
All the skins, cores, and seeds—
Now a worm's all it needs—
Boil in water, then strain and partake.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Georgian buildings: these show great restraint;
Neoclassical lines; brick (no paint).
But chinoiserie, too,
And the Gothick, imbue
Georgian structures. Laid-back? Those just ain't.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The surgeon who did my cosmetic
Procedure was much too frenetic.
My nose job and tuck
Went bizarrely amok.
Now my tummy and schnozz are prosthetic.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
Geography teacher Miss Meyers
Distributed numerous flyers.
They showed the main alley
In "Waterworks Valley"
In Jersey (the water suppliers).

limerick_list.author: David Bourke
limerick_list.text:
An aperture is a small hole
In a camera, the "stop" its control.
The more light revealed,
The less depth of field.
Get it right, or you'll waste the whole roll.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
Is it digital video disk,
Or would I be taking a risk
If I used the word versatile
For the V?  Oh, just curse it, I'll
Say DVD — that's more brisk.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
We write limericks, each to define
A new word, but each one in a line
Alphabetical, so
We will never reach O
In my lifetime. Still, watch out for mine:

I've decided my primary aim
Is to write in advance; achieve fame.
So I've penned quite a few
On obedient, ooh,
And oft — got ahead of the game!

limerick_list.author: johng
limerick_list.text:
This enamelled or tin cooking pot
May be used by the campfire  a lot.
It is known as a billy.
Can be used willy-nilly—
And the lid keeps your tea piping hot.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
To the jury, the DA expressed
His belief the men under arrest
Were all guilty. "I'm going
To prove this by showing
They're villains that good folk detest."

limerick_list.author: Chavi Beck
limerick_list.text:
As you sail between Denmark and Sweden
Through the Kattegat strait, please be heedin'
All the treacherous rocks!
Wish your boat had some shocks
To absorb every unfriendly greetin'.

limerick_list.author: SusanL and Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
A disqualifying foul was just made
And the league's set the price to be paid:
You've been mean on the field
And your actions will yield
A suspension from games yet unplayed.

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
"Don't go in there, you fool! See it fume?
Though there's fire, there's no air in that room.
If you open the door
We'll have backdraught galore!"
So he opened the window and…

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
Anti-Jewish is such a sad word,
For it flows from the awe of the herd.
Wherever Jews settle
They show their rare mettle,
And envy then often gets stirred.

limerick_list.author: Jeter Coffee
limerick_list.text:
My wife sidled up just to say,
"Do you know it's St. Valentine's Day?
That's a date we should keep:
If you weren't so dang cheap,
We could dine at the Hog Trough Buffet."

limerick_list.author: Prolix3
limerick_list.text:
A tough cut of meat is the brisket.
For cooks it's not clever to risk it,
For when served to a party,
They'll fail to eat hearty,
And many will fill up on biscuit.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
The starfishes don't seem convivial,
So their parties are boring and trivial;
But when two of them meet,
They can wave their tube feet
In a two-legged greeting that's bivial.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
The gewgaw's a fun thing to play:
Hold by lips (against teeth), pluck away,
Move the tongue to change pitch.
Now when I have the itch,
I twang Mozart's sonata in A.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
California rolls, lacking raw fish,
Are a sushi: a "Japanese" dish.
When toro was lacking,
Avocados, lip-smacking,
Filled in with cooked crab; they're delish.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
I'm on Facebook by day and by night.
My followers like what I write.
I've got invites and friends.
I've got feeds to the trends.
But have I got a life? No, not quite.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Alphabet and speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
He proclaimed himself "Gunther the Great!"
But his subjects said, "Abdicate, mate!"
While they rallied each night,
His old visage grew white:
Albication from fearing his fate.

limerick_list.author: Joanna Keene
limerick_list.text:
He's a gadfly, that critical lout;
All his time is spent chewing us out.
Every day is a test
With that nit-picking pest —
What a shame that he's got so much clout!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
"He expects we will beat him full sore —
Knows full well he'll bear welts by the score.
Should we bludgeon that knave
Till he's nigh in his grave?"
"He's a masochist; what are friends for?"

limerick_list.author: hugh t.
limerick_list.text:
"What's that creature?" I asked Gerald Durrell.
He replied: "I should say it's a bharal,
'Cause it bleats 'bhaa, bhaa, bhaa'.
I can't tell from this far
If the beast is a bhoy or a gharal."

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
He's a crackerjack salesman, you bet,
And as cool as a Mozart quartet.
He's determined which stars
Love collectible cars,
And who must own a vintage Corvette.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Profound conflicts in novels seem real.
They've a near-universal appeal.
We're distracted by actions;
Ideas are abstractions,
But those moral dilemmas we feel.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
This amazingly great hymnal fave
Was writ by a preacher, once slave-
Trader! How can this be?
God's wonders, we see,
May result in the song this man gave.

limerick_list.author: sallycello
limerick_list.text:
A Byzantinist studies the past
Of an empire doomed not to last.
His quest for the story
Of Byzantine glory
Brings tales of great riches amassed.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
This contagium? I'm undesirous
Of having this red swollen iris
And pain in my eye,
But at least I know why—
It is caused by a microbe or virus.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The cut called Culebra began
In the days when the French had a plan
For a sea-level route
To be dug, a pursuit
That brought misery to many a man.

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
With my dial-up, the service connected
So slowly, I finally defected
To cable: dramatic,
That change — I'm ecstatic!
My problems are now all corrected.

limerick_list.author: Seth Brown
limerick_list.text:
In the Hague, there's a judge I once knew
Who from Amsterdam came by canoe.
 He said, "Clogged though it be,
 It's my hometown, you see,
And I'd love to go back, wooden shoe?"

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Cardiopathy's playing a part
In his troubles, and so is a tart.
His cholesterol's high;
Now this hooker says bye,
And he loves her. It's breaking his heart.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
An ace: what a tennis pro gains
When a point on one serve he attains.
Or he might be an ace
As in "King of Airspace"
If he shoots down five enemy planes.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
With my paper and pens I'm equipped
To write beautiful, fine, fancy script.
I think I'll use pink-
hued calligraphy ink—
Oops! I must start again! That page ripped!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Intellectual subjects are these:
Modern art, metaphysics, Chinese.
My cerebral pursuits
Show my lower-class roots:
Velvet Elvises, bowling, and sleaze.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
Want to help hunt the skies for ET?
Or predict what the climate will be?
Lots of projects to choose;
PC networks they use.
It's all done with BOINC.

limerick_list.author: jexia
limerick_list.text:
<% Response.Write("If your pages are built on the server") %>
<% Response.Write("To dynamically suit each observer—") %>
<% Response.Write("The content is active") %>
<% Response.Write("(A feature attractive") %>
<% Response.Write("Enough to excite quite a fervour).") %>

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
If you want to date someone like me,
Your new car must be something to see.
You must have a fine residence
And lots of dead presidents
To spend. You don't get me for free!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Many orchids, camellias, and roses—
Those delights to our eyes and our noses—
Are cultivars too.
Try to sell them and you
May be hauled into court, one supposes.

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
The achenial sunflower seed
Is a wonderful product, indeed.
What we think is the shell
Is a fruit just as well,
But it's dry and it's thin-walled, agreed?

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A genetic chimera? That means
That your cells have distinct sets of genes
From two fertilized eggs—
A condition that begs
For deployment in horror-film scenes.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Shed a tear for the dhaman, a snake.
From its hide, ladies' shoes people make,
And they also make purses.
This colubrid's curse is
Its beautiful skin—a mistake.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
"In the coolth of the still autumn night,
They were..." "Pardon, that doesn't sound right.
That t-h there on cool—
What's it for?" "You poor fool,
It's like length, width or warmth." "So, why height?"

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
My leg has been injured since I
Forgot armor that covers my thigh.
The cuish, made of leather,
Protects in all weather,
But I didn't wear one—oh my!

limerick_list.author: hugh t.
limerick_list.text:
Said the bailiff, "Ya see this 'ere capias?"
I looked: I had just been as happy as
Could be; that was gone
As the fellow went on:
"It means I'm arresting your crappy ass."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The Ayrshires are milkers, I've read,
Hardy cattle the Scottish have bred.
They're at ease in the stall,
With good udders . . . that's all
I recall off the top of my head.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Hallucinogenics? Don't sniff any.
Few are good for your well-being, if any.
There's no life revelations,
Deep realizations
From substance abuse — no epiphany.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
In the '50s, Lord Mancroft once said
That from Bristol, no prisoner fled.
"If escapes make the news,
We don't say that. We use
Dematerialization instead."

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
Though I'm fearful of clowns and of heights,
I refuse to be ruled by my frights.
Counterphobic, I choose
To wear floppy red shoes
And perform on trapezes in tights.

limerick_list.author: VERaLOE
limerick_list.text:
New York's called the Empire State.
It has sixty-two counties to date,
Like St. Lawrence, Oswego,
Monroe, and Otsego,
Whose Hall of Fame (baseball) is great.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
She sang country and crossover pop.
Raw emotion led straight to the top.
Patsy Cline would assert,
"I just sing like I hurt
Inside."  Truly, the cream of the crop.

limerick_list.author: waterrocks
limerick_list.text:
If it's shipshape, it's quite Bristol fashion,
And won't make the Captain turn ashen:
He loves things just right,
Clean and sparkling bright,
And a mess drives him into a passion.

limerick_list.author: olwen
limerick_list.text:
The first rose of the summer you'll see
Will be banksia — blossoming free.
Its small yellow flowers
Will smother your bowers,
And it might even climb up a tree.

limerick_list.author: Jesse Frankovich
limerick_list.text:
The more of my money I bet,
The more in return I shall net!
But, of course, should I lose,
I'll be singing the blues
As each bet, I regret, becomes debt.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Concentrated, this juice really oughta
Be diluted. But if I add water,
It won't be so thick,
And the sugar won't stick,
So it won't rot the teeth of my daughter.

limerick_list.author: bestswanbird
limerick_list.text:
These days, button fly trousers are rare,
As a zip is thought more debonair.
Bet it made lovers grumble
When men had to fumble.
And what if he hadn't a spare?

limerick_list.author: Type A
limerick_list.text:
When in Maine, if "ayuh" you should hear
In response to your question, don't fear:
We're denoting accord,
And mean nothing untoward—
It means "yes" to the people up here.

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
It's the mango I crave most of all:
The Ataulfo — sweet, yellow, and small.
I am putting my money
On that little honey.
You got any? Gimme a call.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Words like field goal and fine-grain appear
In a list of abbrevs. They are here
Under entry: FG—
Adding fuel gas makes three
Different meanings, which context can clear.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
In Dunedin, a beer-drinking student
Drank more than was actually prudent.
The eager young scarfie
Was soon feeling barfy,
Digestible contents protrudent.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
The churchman has thought to retire,
As his sermons all fail to inspire.
He's convinced he's a bore
'Cuz the rush to the door
Leaves him preaching (ahem) to the choir.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
This morning, it rained—just a shower—
A dust settler, gone in an hour,
So barely worth mention.
But what got our attention?
Desert flora erupting in flower.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Said Camilla, "It's Charles I adore;
Though I'm wearing his ring, I want more!"
So she sought souvenirs,
Like the cans from his beers,
And was bronzing the shoes that he wore.

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
As she dropped it deep into the oil,
I was sure that my Mars Bar would spoil,
But delicious and thick,
It did not make me sick,
Though the thought of it made me recoil.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
A fabricant's someone who makes
A product. His factory takes
What we call raw material
And, in steps that are serial,
Makes brake pads or steak knives or rakes.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
When a pair holds dissimilar views
About marriage, a conflict ensues.
Alice wants to wed Marc;
Marc thinks life is a lark.
She hears wedding bells. He hears kazoos.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In Spain, after eating your fill,
If you leave without paying your bill,
The host may object,
And your path intersect
With a constable called alguazil.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Decorum's been sliding downhill,
And the atmosphere's charged with ill will:
Graphic threats fill the air
Mixed with cries of "Unfair!"
Guess the unions don't care for this bill.

limerick_list.author: S. A. McBurnie and Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
The flat butter bean often is seen
In Hispanic and Southern cuisine:
In your tapas; in stew;
In your succotash, too.
Some are whitish, while some are picked green.

limerick_list.author: danmcgrath
limerick_list.text:
My e-learning course on the net?
It's high tech for the indolent set.
See, the prof is a bot,
And those mind pills it's got
Let you download and never forget.

limerick_list.author: Anonymity
limerick_list.text:
Have a cancerous prostate or breast?
Goserelin may treat it the best.
It keeps sex hormones low
So the cancer won't grow.
See a doctor before you invest!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Something porcine exhibits its porkiness.
A wood plug in a bottle shows corkiness.
If you're dumb, gauche, and loud,
Then shout out in a crowd,
You are proudly displaying your dorkiness.

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
I'm a student of avian life.
With nine parrots my cottage is rife.
But at times when they screech
I'm devoid of all speech,
And I dash off in search of a knife.

limerick_list.author: mino
limerick_list.text:
An argument might cause much strife,
Especially one with your wife.
It could last just a minute
If her heart isn't in it —
If it is? Try the rest of your life.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
Colla voce: th' accompanist's sign
That rubato or stretto's "not mine",
To not play what I read:
Let the voice take the lead.
Setting tempo's the soloist's line.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
What a racket last night when they threw
Out some drunks, and the arguments grew
On the street.  I'd no notion
A minor commotion
Would cause such a hullabaloo.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers and SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Every decade, the census invasion
Means I'm asked for my racial persuasion.
I keep telling the man
That I'm beige-pinkish-tan,
But he wants me to say I'm Caucasian.

limerick_list.author: Comicoffee
limerick_list.text:
Your retail expansion's unwise
If you don't know the market's true size.
Twenty stores in this town
Will cause sales to go down,
Since your sites will all cannibalize.

limerick_list.author: AndrewB
limerick_list.text:
This new power source needs to be checked,
So a dummy load's what we connect.
Should there be something wrong,
We will know before long,
So a defect we'll safely detect.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin and Virge
limerick_list.text:
When longing for treats hot and steamy,
A Wild Westerner's thoughts could turn seamy.
"Is that, Davy Crockett,
An aardvark in your pocket,
Or are you just happy to see me?"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Marcie's famed for her numerous flings.
While so many are joyless, she swings.
Through her countless affairs
No one's hurt, so who cares?
They mean zip in the grand scheme of things.

limerick_list.author: PdeG and mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Define this? I really cannot,
And this verse will assist not-a-lot.
And I'll cheerfully grant
That the reason I can't
Is that frankly I don't give a jot.

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
On an architect's desk, one may see
A few technical sketches (croquis):
Maybe chic Arts and Crafts,
And although just rough drafts,
They're remotely backed-up on CD.

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
I once knew a talented fella
Who sang by himself a cappella.
Without breaking sweat
He'd perform a duet —
How he did it is too rude to tell-a.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In our house in the woods, for the nonce,
Dearest treasure, I'd like to ensconce
Our two souls.  Deep inside,
Settled snugly, we'll hide.
Texts and emails will get no response.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
"The chaos in here," said my boss,
"Or a rock you can't climb is called choss";
But the chaos my boss meant
Wasn't what my friend Ross meant
When he slipped climbing choss slick with moss.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
In a counterexample, the aim
Is disproving a theorem or claim.
Lucas gave it a go.
Now the fallacies show
In von Neumann and Morgenstern's game.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
A report by an airport surveyor,
On an airport's main baggage conveyor,
Said it no way conforms
To design safety norms
One expects of a state's major player.

He also prepared a report
On a new docking pier, and sought
To list major flaws—
Its main schedule ensures
The designer will end up in court.

limerick_list.author: GalFisk
limerick_list.text:
"Electron guns, that's what they're called,
And they shoot—" Mom was shocked and appalled.
"Mister, no more TV!
Seems whatever you see
Involves weapons and violence!" she bawled.

limerick_list.author: Qermaq
limerick_list.text:
Once a rude little boy named Jerome
Took some thick polyurethane foam
From the arm of the love seat
And made his mom's doves eat
It all! (Please don't try this at home.)

limerick_list.author: Steve Ngai
limerick_list.text:
Here's a musical joy that I know:
Chorale preludes. To these, I let go
As the ancient notes soar
On their slow-moving score
While the tumult is raging below.

limerick_list.author: Nan
limerick_list.text:
An abbé who was based in Quebec
Said, "This abbey is one total wreck.
To fix the church spire
I'm planning to hire
Engineers from L'École Polytech."*

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
"It's a bomb site!" I yelled as I ambled
Through debris piled high. My son rambled
Defensively, "Dad!
It's my room, don't get mad.
Where've you gone?!" (He should care!) Out I scrambled!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Such embryonate conduct I had:
Nascent, immature deeds, as a lad.
Now I'm seasoned and wise;
So to no one's surprise,
I'm now acting exactly like Dad.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My repair will be fully corrective;
Your leg will be strong, not defective.
My technique, diorthotic,
Is sound, not quixotic,
When applied with my expert perspective.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
My libido I've kept in a headlock:
With my celibate vow there was deadlock.
But it's getting much harder
To stifle my ardour
Since finding I'd just forsworn wedlock.

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
My sweetheart since high school, named Heather,
From birth, had her lips stuck together;
Had an adhesiotomy,
First shouted "Aha!" to me
Then added: "What's up with this weather?"

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
French novels are sexy and spicy;
Use French letters for sex that is dicey.
If your language slips past
What's polite, then a fast
"'Scuse my French" adds a note nicey-nicey.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
We've ascended so high in the skies
That our airplane can no longer rise.
At this absolute ceiling,
I'm getting the feeling
A parachute might have been wise.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
To the breach, my dear friends, let's deploy
And embattle our troops, then destroy
Those whose sabres they rattle.
Let's slay them like cattle,
For that'll bring all of us joy.

limerick_list.author: Andrew Burnet
limerick_list.text:
Independence day looms: the flag flies.
Antiseparatist sentiments rise
In those parts of the nation
Where unification
Is felt to promote bluer skies.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
My friend said, "I'm fleet on my feet
When encountering gals who've been beat
With an ugly stick."  "But,"
I informed him, "know what?
I'm sure looking at you is no treat."

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
At the chessboard: c2 to c3.
'Twas as simple as simple  could be.
From g6 came Fred's queen
Which I just hadn't seen,
And he sure got the better of me.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Yonder maiden I spy is a belle. A
Bold feller I am, so I'll tell 'er.
(Love to loosen thy corset —
Gadzooks, lad, don't force it.)
"Thy donzel salutes damosella."

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
The stock in our company fell.
And our boss?  He dismissed personnel.
I'm just one of a mass
Whom he kicked in the ass.
Hope this bloodletting jerk lands in hell.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Cowboys sing as they herd; they don't prattle.
If they warble sweet melodies, that'll
Give livestock a lift
As they pass down the drift-
way—the road used for driving their cattle.

limerick_list.author: Bill Cernansky
limerick_list.text:
In the hallways, my monitor duties
I ably performed, despite cuties
Who steamed up my glasses
While begging for passes
And left me with cases of cooties.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
The insurers said, "Thanks for your claim;
You're underinsured, all the same.
So you won't get the actual
Cash value; in fact, you'll
Get fifty percent—what a shame."

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
Bye-bye, butter, milk, yoghurt and cheese.
There are sugars and proteins in these
Of which I must be wary:
Allergic to dairy,
I don't want to scratch, belch or wheeze.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Doktor Freud caused indignant, loud screams,
When he set up dream symbols and schemes
To interpret the id,
Where we secretly hid
What cigars might (uhm) stand for in dreams.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Army Air Corps is nearly an airforce —
The infantry might call it their force;
For tars, the Fleet Air Arm
Is more of a rare arm:
With budget cuts, no-one has spare force.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Dolorimetry measures your pain
As I turn up the voltage again.
You look very relaxed
As the meter is maxed;
If I killed you, I twiddled in vain.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Cream of tartar—it grows on a tree?
Now, I'm asking you—how can this be?
Is it just one more wonder
Of wild life Down Under,
Where wombats and roos all run free?

limerick_list.author: birdbarf
limerick_list.text:
A good bush pilot's willing to fly
Into wilderness just to supply
Things to help folks survive:
Food to keep them alive,
And some Mace for a polar bear's eye.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
GPS, mp3, tiny phone,
Bluetooth earbuds, HD camera drone —
Electronic devices!
Affordable prices!
My gadgetry! All I can own!

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
With the sound of a freight train, or thunder,
The tornado descends, and we wonder
From here, underground,
Is our home safe and sound?
Or completely destroyed, torn asunder?

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
College football?  We're grossly mismatched
And our coach will, I'm sure, be dispatched.
Every run's like a crawl
When we carry the ball.
Every pass that we throw goes uncatched.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
That loud priest puts his words on display
Every day, when he hears himself pray.
He thinks all must rejoice
At his resonant voice —
Every ass likes to hear himself bray.

limerick_list.author: Richard English
limerick_list.text:
When writing, Philology Pete
Finds anapaest feet rather neat.
One syllable's stressed
(A long one is best)
Which follows two short ones that greet.

limerick_list.author: zqms
limerick_list.text:
See that mousehole right there? Have a glance:
Soon a mouse may emerge and advance.
Then the first part he shows,
Will, I guess, be his nose.
If the mouse has moved house though? No chance.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
I wanted to write of aboulia,
Defining it fully to schoolia.
But my willpower's lost,
And we'll both bear the cost
Of a mindset that does overrulia.

limerick_list.author: Errol Nimbly
limerick_list.text:
Straight into the shop the boy gazed,
Through two panes with an air-space, amazed.
He'd eat six, he soon reckons
(As white topping beckons),
For, double, not single, they're glazed.

limerick_list.author: R. A. Shortfellow
limerick_list.text:
I'm a vital young man in my prime:
A creature of form so sublime.
Yet I've always feared Death,
Who will force my last breath,
And it's said he could come anyti

limerick_list.author: Reia Light
limerick_list.text:
My great-aunt has a curio rack
Stuffed full of the worst bric-a-brac—
Happy porcelain kittens,
Pink ducks wearing mittens,
And tap-dancing pigs in the back.

limerick_list.author: Jane Auerbach
limerick_list.text:
Dick Clark built success after school:
Philly teens danced on Bandstand, looked cool
As groups lip-synced to hits,
Selling records. Clark's wits
Let him profit, no pay-for-play fool.

limerick_list.author: Recumbentman
limerick_list.text:
A dog, without pause or deflection,
Will solve any maze to perfection.
One sniff, and he legs it
Direct to the exit—
Amazing, the scents of direction.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
Happy birthday, you're 18 at last.
You're an adult; your childhood has passed.
But inside, still, the child
That was born free and wild
Needs to guard you from ageing too fast.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Now me and my big brother Tommy,
Received a stern letter from Mommy.
She delivered a scolding:
"Heard your business was folding!"
"But Mom, our firm makes origami."

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
When the colors of toner run low,
But the cyan and yellow still show,
We make duotone prints,
Which use only two tints.
This process is "green", you should know.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The cheese Crocodile Tear, loved by many,
Appeared on my cheesy antennae.
Shaped like Hershey's famed kisses,
In the Brie family this is,
But crocodile milk? No, not any.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A baby banana is sweeter
To the typical yellow fruit eater.
While it's true you may find
A more flavorful kind,
It's not likely there's any petiter.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Can you abrogate wills?  I'm revoking
My testament.  Offspring are choking.
I am leaving them poor.
Said my daughter, "Now you're
Almost certainly, horribly joking!"

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I observed a Eurasian green toad,
And a mighty fine color it showed.
Did its beautiful green
 Make it linger to preen?
Such a shame it was squashed on the road!

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
I'm called Prince (since JC's known as King)
Of the Church. You, dear pilgrims, will sing
Of our Holiness. Kneeling
At audience, feeling
Devout, pucker up: kiss my ring.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Now the honor was his, as his right:
Pure of heart, he'd be belted in white.
So he knelt by the Queen
In this time-honoured scene,
And arose newly dubbed "belted knight."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The three men were, of course, not bereft,
Since there now was no evidence left.
With the body plumb gone
From the victim's front lawn,
They would not be reporting the theft.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
This hide's huge; it will take me an hour
To remove its top layer (efflower).
Of course, there's remorse
That I shot my old horse.
He's to blame, though: he'd lost his horse power.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
From my snooze, I awoke to the stews'
Cries for women and children, in queues.
Was I on the Titanic?
What could cause all this panic?
It was Spam on our Carnival cruise.

limerick_list.author: jexia
limerick_list.text:
It's seven?  Too soon to be waking.
Eleven?  My belly is aching.
It's time for my brunch.
(That's like breakfast and lunch
All in one. So you'd better start baking.)

limerick_list.author: waterrocks
limerick_list.text:
If it seems that you merely survive —
Just exist — don't feel thankful or thrive,
Simply pause for one breath —
Not to think about death,
But to savour that instant alive.

limerick_list.author: Quickbeam
limerick_list.text:
If a bev'rage or chemical firm should
Suggest mixing something with wormwood,
The instructions would state
Simply "absinthiate,"
Which defines it as no other term would.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Before my exams I can pass,
I must show I can make polished glass.
The instructor? She rates
How I fire polish plates.
(In the heat, make them shiny—first class!)

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
Aviv was the month in the spring
Ancient Jews did the Passover thing,
Thanking God he took care o'
That horrible Pharaoh
(A shonda he ever made King!).

limerick_list.author: Dave Jermy
limerick_list.text:
"That makes three in the over," I grouch,
As another high ball makes me crouch.
I'm in fear for my skin,
And would rather face spin
Than this barrage of chin music. Ouch!

limerick_list.author: Smife
limerick_list.text:
When she moaned the wrong name to her lover,
As he eagerly hovered above her,
He hoped this tongue trip
Was no Freudian slip,
Or their love life would never recover.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
How to discipline cronies and buddies
Is her discipline (subject of studies).
As an expert on whips,
She will offer free tips
To well-disciplined students she bloodies.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Citrus maxima grows out in Asia.
Its name's grandiose, and may faze ya.
The fruits that it bears
Are much larger than pears—
More like grapefruits—that shouldn't amaze ya.

limerick_list.author: Richard English
limerick_list.text:
Dry cell: an electric device
That gives out its amps in a trice.
And it's sealed up as well
(Unlike a wet cell)
So for moving around it's quite nice.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I learned from an actress (my momma)
That a serious play is a drama,
And in south Alabama
They never say "drama."
They rhyme it with llama or comma.

limerick_list.author: Graham Guest
limerick_list.text:
The carpenter old Mister Barber
Is still fixing wood to my arbour.
To my endless regret,
He has not finished yet.
He is certainly no homo faber.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
Narcissus received true affection
With nary a chance of rejection.
But the love that he found
Could have gotten him drowned.
His perceptiveness lacked self-reflection.

limerick_list.author: Kalleh
limerick_list.text:
Analgesics eliminate pains.
Overdoses degenerate brains.
They're needed for buffering
Aches one is suffering,
But never for pains that one feigns.

limerick_list.author: GalFisk
limerick_list.text:
All bad words met with e-radication
Automatically, no hesitation.
But computers will make
The clbuttic mistake,
And necessitate buttbuttination.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Being sick, in itself, is a curse.
Comorbidities make it much worse—
Even harder than hell
To become really well—
And a drain, sad to tell, on the purse.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Adenomatous tumor of mine,
I declare you're a cinch to define:
You start out in a gland,
But won't get out of hand
Because (best of all traits) you're benign!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I felt jubilant, joyful, yes, festive,
Till Yule gluttony led to bowels restive.
Gobbling turkey galore
Plus those pies (and much more!)
Soon engendered disturbance digestive.

limerick_list.author: Jared Wright (LimerickLife)
limerick_list.text:
Add this to taxonomy files:
Scaly creatures of various styles—
And those who are wiser
Avoid the incisor
When one from Diapsida smiles.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
As a youngster, she bears rounded swipes
In loud blue and bright white — camo types.
If she makes three years old,
She'll be striped blue and gold.
You could say she has earned her bold stripes.

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
Fixing corrie to wood I used gum,
Which, in retrospect, seems rather dumb.
Using clout nails instead,
I bang each on the head—
Oh damn! I've just clouted my thumb!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
It's the job that I do when I'm home;
I'm the dishwasher named in this poem.
First my spouse cooks a meal,
Then we eat it with zeal—
Then I'm up to my elbows in foam.

limerick_list.author: Kevin
limerick_list.text:
There was a young lady named Mandy
Who got totally soused drinking brandy.
She had a long snooze
Brought about by the booze,
Which she thought had been nothing but shandy.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Though, for counseling, Lee pays a fee,
With her counselor she'll disagree.
As she storms out the door,
He yells, "I'm coun-sel-OR!
You're expected to be counselee."

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick
limerick_list.text:
Ain't I glad, on this earth I was born a
Fine specimen classified fauna.
Given flora, my lot
Might have been a clay pot—
Just a parlor palm stuck in the corner.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Entrepreneurialism sets me aflame!
To start and run firms is my aim.
My whole stake is at stake
For each risk that I take,
Because "Flourish Or Fail!" is my game.

limerick_list.author: otherwisefine
limerick_list.text:
They want me to plough the backyard,
But just scratching the surface is hard
With this quite categoric-
ally most prehistoric
Scratch-plough that is known as an ard.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Site of memories sweet, and some sour,
By which leaders cruise hour by hour,
It's a park in D.C.
Whence the White House you'll see:
The Ellipse, at the center of power.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
A deplorate old boozer I knew
Couldn't keep his libations to two.
He'd down the whole case
At a pretty quick pace;
Then he'd wake up and ask for a brew.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
In dolor I drift. I'm morose
'Cause I heard you've contracted a dose
Of the clap. While I'm sad
That you're feeling so bad,
My regret's that one night we got close.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
He would challenge The Wiz if he durst,
But he practiced his spellcasting first.
For a while, he rehearsed,
'Til his hex got reversed.
'Twas the worst. He got curst. Then he burst.

limerick_list.author: Doug Smeath
limerick_list.text:
If your aim is impressing the girls,
Then be careful selecting their pearls.
You'll be seen as a joke
If your gift is baroque.
A misshapen adornment's for churls.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Grandma Nasty" just died and it sucks
That she left me her porcelain ducks.
Uncle Ned, it appears,
Now sheds crocodile tears.
He inherited six million bucks.

limerick_list.author: Kalleh
limerick_list.text:
"If you think I am going to take
Your insults..." [...you make a mistake].
That rhet'ric device
Is the overconcise
Anapodoton — no, it's not fake!

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
There's no reason that you should connive
To resuscitate ancient descrive;
Rest in peace, then. It's better
To alter one letter:
Describe (v to b) comes alive.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel
limerick_list.text:
This bubblegum flavor's a new chew;
It's a marketing-research-to-do chew.
Where's it made? Chattanooga.
Will taste buds ah-ooh-ga?
Will bubbles be blown with this chew-chew?

limerick_list.author: Rudi
limerick_list.text:
When a critic stays hidden and faceless,
And whispers opinions so baseless
As to call my art, smugly,
"Uncultured and ugly,"
It's he, not his target, who's graceless.

limerick_list.author: David Schildkret
limerick_list.text:
That puppy's so peripatetic,
His energy's really frenetic.
He loves chasing balls
Through the rooms and the halls—
How I wish he'd become akinetic!

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
In Macbeth, dagger drawn, a great actor
Heard the voice of a vicious detracter.
"This is absolute balls!"
She opined from the stalls
(In her death, a significant factor).

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
Why talk apathy? Who needs to know?
What's the difference? They'll still steal the show.
Things are always resolved.
Why should I get involved?
C'est la vie, pal. I'll go with the flow.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Though I saw you two kiss, you're maintaining
Your innocence, sadly explaining,
"He's kin."  Kin don't kiss
Quite like that, so don't piss
On my leg and then tell me it's raining.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
This enthused bunch of techies can crunch
All our numbers so fast, I've a hunch
They're mathematical mystics
Who dine on statistics,
Eat Fourier series for lunch!

limerick_list.author: BobfromThirsk
limerick_list.text:
When the tip of your drill wants to wander
All hither and thither and yonder,
I've a kind of a hunch
That a good centre punch
Is a tool that you really should ponder.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
Pastel-colored pillows so sweet,
After-dinner mints make a good treat.
Though I've seen variations
Of these minty temptations,
They all are confections we eat.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Let your voice be a gentle caress,
Speaking softly, my darling, unless
There's a point you must make.
Then speak up for God's sake.
What you'd emphasize—that you must stress.

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
In a flash, at the drop of a hat,
Without further ado, just like that,
In the blink of an eye,
It's that old custard pie,
And your dignity's gone with a splat!

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
I don't care what you say, Dad, okay?
I am not going outside to play.
Sure, I like playing games
With Jemima and James,
But abide by your ruling? No way!

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
You serve, I return with a dink
(This will certainly make your eyes blink).
I play softly, and yet
The ball's over the net,
Then abruptly it's starting to sink.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
I said, "Doc, I need help, if you please,
As my emrods are down to my knees."
On his finger he smeared
A thick goo as he peered:
"Severe hemorrhoids! A painful disease."

limerick_list.author: Jeter Coffee
limerick_list.text:
If your flight is cut short, you'll be late.
Is your marriage cut short?  Blame your mate.
With Procrustean cuts,
There aren't ifs, ands, or buts —
They're a shortcut to quick loss of weight.

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
War's over! Demobilization
Will follow the conflict's cessation.
Pack their tents, turn in swords,
No more fighting — move towards
A pacific and civilized nation.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Dalmatians are white with black dots—
Dogs that live in unusual spots.
In the firehouse, they're pets;
It's as good as it gets.
They get love, food, and exercise—lots!

limerick_list.author: Rudi
limerick_list.text:
When I see something gruesome, I grue:
I shudder and shiver, I do—
That's until someone toothsome
Approaches. I'm truthsome.
"Screw grueing!" I'll think, "Can we screw?"

limerick_list.author: Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
Let us thunder again Brontosaurus
("Thunder lizard") — a name we can chorus.
But apatosaur's weak
("Tricksy lizard" in Greek) —
We've been cheated by who came before us!

limerick_list.author: Screenhog
limerick_list.text:
Played the cowbell in band class at school.
It was all they'd allow me, how cruel.
Then they found the agogo–
Two cowbells from Togo–
And then I felt doubly the fool.

limerick_list.author: S. A. McBurnie
limerick_list.text:
My optometrist offers no hope;
When his office anomaloscope
Showed me red, I saw green.
That infernal machine
Says I'm colorblind.  How will I cope?

limerick_list.author: Suzanne Kreul
limerick_list.text:
In childhood, it's bedtime at eight,
And you dream of adulthood — can't wait!
Once you're grown, you'll be free
To stay up way past three,
But by then you won't want to. (That's fate.)

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A nibble of cake has educed
A remembrance of passion for Proust:
A petite boulangère
With a sweet derrière,
An affair, and a cook being goosed.

limerick_list.author: hwindle
limerick_list.text:
Let me try a new opening gambit.
I may lose, but I don't care a damn bit.
Though they all end the same,
I play game after game.
With the chess-playing bug, I sure am bit.

limerick_list.author: pöt
limerick_list.text:
The history of Europe between
Fifteen hundred and roughly eighteen
Hundred specialists name
Early modern. The same
Term for English (then spoken) is seen.

limerick_list.author: alan meyer
limerick_list.text:
The culicines (students, take heed)
Spread human disease when they feed.
Her proboscis injected?
You might be infected!
Malignant mosquitoes indeed.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Your employers implored you, "Restore the rate
Of returns," but it still remained poor, the rate.
Says the board, "CEO,
We regret, you must go.
Therefore you we do hereby exauthorate."

limerick_list.author: a.groovymind
limerick_list.text:
"There's a soft spot, see, right in the middle,"
Said the quack, "but for me that's no riddle.
I'll just smear some smegma
On top of his bregma —
Then your child will be fit as a fiddle!"

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
I want to get in on this game.
It's a field where I might make my name:
Knitting squares (got the bug!)
For the World's Biggest Rug —
What — they've got it sewn up? What a shame!

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
Coproporphyria makes me feel blue.
There's the gut pain. I barf. (Where's the loo?)
Can't drink wine, beer or gin;
Sunlight blisters my skin.
And, well, then there's the name — "purple poo."

limerick_list.author: Harper
limerick_list.text:
Arthritis made Bob lose agility;
Stiff joints gave him lessened mobility.
But his wife, to his joy,
Just gave birth to a boy.
Seems his sperm haven't lost their motility!

limerick_list.author: Graham Lester
limerick_list.text:
The housekeeper's friend NH3
Keeps dwellings bacteria-free.
Germs leave me alone if I
Always ammonify,
And so do my in-laws — yippee!

limerick_list.author: J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
The architect stopped by and halted
Construction; he screamed, then assaulted
My boss for revealing
The wrong type of ceiling:
Not angled, but round (barrel-vaulted).

limerick_list.author: rbalexx
limerick_list.text:
Very funny.  You bastard, you lied.
That's a chilli; my lips are now fried.
On the life of your child
You swear capsicum's mild.
One more joke: it's your fault that he died.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
As I sought breaths of air (there were none,
Not one puff), Jack returned from his run.
He had B.O. to spare;
I took one breath of heir
And beseeched, "Buy deodorant, son!"

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
When the gas gauge reads "F" one assumes
That no threat of a gas shortage looms,
But my hard-up friend Jeff
Says, "Not so! That's low F.
We are running completely on fumes."

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
"Once befuddlement's muddied our brains,
It's tenacious," Doc Addler explains.
"Minds too long out of whack
Become tough nuts to crack
When such adamant addlement reigns."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The professor who spoke on geology
Owes his students an abject apology.
What he gave as a speech
Called Why Sand Coats the Beach
Was a mass of confusing cacology.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
The pain caused insane desperation.
Dexamethasone eased my frustration
From my asthma, arthritis,
And acute dermatitis—
A sensational new medication!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Taking fibers from hemp, from its core,
After retting: you break. For this chore
Of pre-scotching, well suited
Are rollers (they're fluted).
That's it. I can't say any more.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
As he worked on his puzzle (acrostic),
He said, "Damn it, these words make my jaw stick!"
She looked at him fox-eyed—
"Drink sodium hydroxide!"
Do you think her response was too caustic?

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
There's this room where two people are mergin'
That's real dark like you might sing a dirge in.
The groom's got this hat,
And the bride's short and fat
And wears green, so that means she's no virgin.

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Had a mule and she had what it takes
To haul goods up-canal to great lakes.
My good mule (her name's Sal)
Trod the Erie Canal
And died pulling. I guess that's the breaks.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
"Ahem" and "ahem" Caleb said,
"Pay attention to me! See my head?
I have written with ink
On my forehead! I think
It is nice, but I should have used red!"

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Think conversate isn't a word
And its use for discuss is absurd?
Well, guess what—it's legit!
So stop throwing a fit.
There are millions who say it, I've heard.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
At a blood house sits Katie O'Grady.
She frequents the squalid and shady,
Like the bars, pubs, cafes,
And hotels where she stays.
And despite what you've heard, she's a lady.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
As the guard locked us in, the door clanged
 And this gallows bird said, "I'll be danged
 If I'm not out by spring."
 Most are betting he'll swing.
 Hell, this bastard deserves to be hanged!

limerick_list.author: LMAK
limerick_list.text:
Near the shore of the old Tethys sea,
Ambulocetus stalked fishes with glee.
With the ears of a whale,
And a walking beast's tail,
This cetacean evolved by degree.

limerick_list.author: TrossL
limerick_list.text:
An antelingual pouch, found near the tongue,
Helps a mama crow feeding her young.
It's a pocket with spare
Bits of carrion bear
She can share with her simps—yum, it's lung!

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
"These old papers reach up to my head!
And there's boxes all over your bed.
All this junk is obscene—
The whole place needs a clean."
"I love trash," Oscar grouchily said.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Bud would bumfuzzle Lou, we all heard,
With some names that were clearly absurd.
Poor Costello, confused,
Felt by Abbott abused:
"I'm not asking you who is on third!"

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
I am going! Don't push. Beating feet!
Get your hands off my neck and my seat!
I'll soon fade out of sight
And just blend into night—
That's me, vanishing there, down your street.

limerick_list.author: operadirector
limerick_list.text:
This convivial fellow named Bart
Is so friendly he must warm your heart —
And his sociable way
Is on constant display.
You can bet that his parties are smart!

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
It's the carrot I have for a nose
That makes people mock, I suppose,
But they shouldn't deride
What they know I can't hide.
(Glad they can't see my blackberry toes!)

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
To impress, I leapt down, arms outspread,
While the chopper's blades whirred overhead.
Whipped by downwash, my tie's
Flapping ends lashed my eyes,
But my hairpiece went walkies instead.

limerick_list.author: James Dobson
limerick_list.text:
An engastrimuth's dummy from Louth,
While on stage with his master down south,
Quipped, "Your hand's in control
Of my body and soul—
But please stop putting words in my mouth."

limerick_list.author: Seth Brown
limerick_list.text:
Troops, we'll lose in a standard attack,
So let's blindside them—strike at their back.
 Where their view is obstructed,
 Let raids be conducted;
We'll pillage, burn, rape, loot, and sack.

limerick_list.author: sallycello
limerick_list.text:
I try to envision humanity
Unflawed by its poisonous vanity.
As guardians of Earth
We should value its worth—
Put a stop to our current insanity.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Betty shot her old husband today.
He's still breathing, though, happy to say.
He'd been out chasing skirts
And was shot where it hurts:
She got him right in the toupee.

Bette caught Douglas last night in mid-hug
With Maureen, who was cute as a bug.
His response? A mere shrug,
But his wife's a real thug.
That's why Doug caught a slug in the rug.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
My money was diffluent, flowing
Away, but just where was it going?
In debt to my neck
'Cause I borrowed like heck,
I don't know how much money I'm owing.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
A migrating rectum? I blink.
Aphredoderus' anus will slink,
Icthyologists note,
From its rear to its throat.
But sayanus ain't what you think.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
My gate to the yard out behind
Doesn't close right. I've looked and I find
That the sun's warped the fence;
In a transitive sense
It deformed it, thus making it bind.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A cherup's a sharp, cheerful noise
Like the one that a cricket employs.
The insecticide crowd
Will complain it's too loud,
But they're people nobuggy enjoys.

limerick_list.author: art bates
limerick_list.text:
A pop man, repairing machines,
Bending over, showed butt 'bove his jeans.
I no doubt should have known
That the slot which was shown
Had no pop-can depositing means.

limerick_list.author: Mad Kane
limerick_list.text:
"We're discussing our favorite dish,"
Said the gal. "Please chime in if you wish."
"You mean Paris and Trump
And that singer's big rump?"
"Oh my no, sir. Our topic is fish."

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Finno-Ugric, of Magyar and Finnish,
Is a language group spread kind of thin-ish.
Sounding odd, they're a struggle
To learn for this muggle
As I age and my talents diminish.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Though clairvoyance may offer the sight
Of a future event, dark or bright,
If you're fearing the worst,
You may feel you've been cursed
While you fret—will the reading be right?

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
If you've not given birth, you're nulliparous.
Having offspring in pairs makes you biparous.
A multiparous wife
Leads a difficult life
If her man's insufficiently zipperous.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
I've wolfed down the chicken tostada,
Ten tacos, and carne asada.
Bring me seven more rounds!
Topping four hundred pounds,
I'm the boss—yeah, the big enchilada.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Since our alehouse ran dry, we've endured
A beer drought. If only our brewer'd
Resume his delivery
Of (now, I feel shivery!)
Glorious, grand, amber fluid.

limerick_list.author: Thomas Taylor
limerick_list.text:
An editor, stumped and perplexed,
Sat confoundedly reading a text;
The hero, one Guido,
Of zero libido,
Had Nero in Speedos! What next?

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
Biosystematics concerns variation
And evolvement of life, in relation
To classifications:
How each population's
Distinct from the last generation.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
In the ocean, "Fall off!" Captain roared.
Robert thought, "Is he out of his gourd?"
I'm sure he'll explain
With discussion profane,
After first pulling Bob back on board.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
These two paintings are hinged, like a book.
On the altar they stand (need no hook).
They relate to each other,
Like sister and brother.
For balance, give each a good look.

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
What adephagous beetles are found?
There are water, and tiger, and ground.
With antennae like threads
On the top of their heads,
They devour all insects around.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The derivative words we create
From constituent parts can elate.
We agglutinate, which
Is the way we enrich
The poor language we all love to hate.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
If we laid all your blood vessels out
End to end (We won't do it — don't pout!),
They would measure, I vow,
A full one hundred thou-
sand miles — and cause mayhem, no doubt!

limerick_list.author: waterrocks
limerick_list.text:
Her courtesy only confirms
She considers us pitiful worms,
Since she's civil — polite —
Whilst repressing her bite.
Good manners, when chilly, cause squirms.

limerick_list.author: EdRush
limerick_list.text:
When we want to speak well of the devil's
Darning needle, we think on two levels:
The ivy takes one,
But the insect's more fun.
Let the darner get on with his revels!

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
It is National Poetry Day,
So there's poetry coming your way.
Here on Radio Two,
With the usual crew,
The Emergency Poet holds sway.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
A switch with a couple of states
(Only two equilibria, mates)
Has been tagged with a label:
It's known as bistable,
Which speaks to just one of its traits.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Like a solenoid, how you attract
Helpless men who, like iron, react
To your pull — like you wield
An electromagnetic field —
You're intelligent, gorgeous, and stacked!

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
A family, teeming with malice,
The Ewings were scheming and callous.
When they ran out of plot,
It was J.R. got shot—
But by whom? You'll just have to watch Dallas.

limerick_list.author: David Roberts
limerick_list.text:
Can it be that the fate of a poet
Is to suffer, unable to show it?
That his poem belies
All the pain in his eyes
That he feels in a world that can't know it?

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
Gordon Bennett went down to the pub,
Where he met with the Euphemists Club.
At their quarterly meeting,
The members were beating
The bushes for curse words to scrub.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
In London, the gate to the east,
Once called Ale-gate, was free for each beast.
Now that Aldgate's its name,
And congestion's the game,
Pay to enter: there's palms to be greased.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
There's a saying I'm sure that you've heard
About using too long of a word
When you write or you speak.
If coherence you seek,
A diminutive word is preferred.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
So you think you know fairy tales, Buddy?
Cinderella is one you should study.
In the Grimm Brothers' tale,
Aschenputtel's not frail,
And the whole thing's remarkably bloody.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
That damn nudist camp watchdog I'll strangle!
I don't care how that looks from his angle.
"Listen, Spot, I am hot,
'Cause that's painful, a lot!"
(When I sit in a deck chair, I dangle.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A brawl in a bar called Mahoney's
Did not include me or my cronies.
We wanted to fight,
But what stopped us that night?
No backbone.  No guts.  No cojones.

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
Besprent is a word from the past;
Its usage today? Far from vast.
Generations ago,
Every priest would well know
It's for those on whom sprinkles are cast.

limerick_list.author: Ritepath
limerick_list.text:
That gruffness is all just a bluff;
Your character's made of fine stuff.
Though outside you're crass,
On the inside: first-class —
You're a definite diamond that's rough.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The event charged three hundred a head,
And the singer knocked everyone dead.
People flocked to the cause
As each speech drew applause.
"A real barnburner!" everyone said.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
This ball's three feet wide. I can lie on it.
On my back, arms spread wide, could I fly on it?
An exercise ball
Keeps me fit. Mustn't fall.
Damn, I'm stuck! Now I fear I might die on it.

limerick_list.author: Jason Talbott
MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I shall read from my ode: "Soon past dawn, he
Cried, "Hark, the sky's fulvous, near tawny,
Red-yellowish brown —
Like fall leaves drifting down…"
Are you bored, class?  You seem a tad yawny.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Ben and Jerry's intent is cryonic,
Chugging antifreeze now as a tonic,
So their organs won't freeze
As they chill by degrees.
Would two corpsicles seem too ironic?

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Here it says genus Ductor is linked
To the jackfish. My book is succinct,
And it says to observe
One that's swimming with verve
Is unlikely—the fish is extinct.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In a cancer the changes are drastic;
The cells have become anaplastic.
They display anaplasia,
A lethal dyscrasia,
Making primitive forms, quite fantastic.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
Alan Ladd — movie star — there's a name.
Five foot five, but could pull any dame.
Once a co-starring wench
Had to walk in a trench
(An adjustment which bolstered his fame).

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
When lava flows runny and slow-y,
It cools to smooth pahoehoe.	
If the strain rate is high
Other forces apply,
And the aa forms, rubbly, not showy.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Sailors thought that safe passage at sea
Was ensured by a gemstone—tee hee!
It was aquamarine
That they brought on the scene,
Superstitious but anxiousness free.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Every winemaker owns a château
Where the price of a bottle may grow
So much faster than wine—
Are they really that fine,
All these overpriced crus de Bordeaux?

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
Brittany spaniels have tails that are short
And have coats of the reddish-brown sort
Or else orange and white.
Large and active, they're quite
Good if hunting for fowl is your sport.

limerick_list.author: Ruchiccio
limerick_list.text:
Squash, meringue, pickles, sushi, red meat,
Ice cream, truffles — these foods I can eat
After gorging on roast,
Deep-fried sausage, French toast...
See, my stomach is made of concrete.

limerick_list.author: Bill Cernansky
limerick_list.text:
Louisa May Alcott was brimmin'
With stories about Little Women.
When she wrote as A. Barnard,
Adult praise was garnered
For tales wild as unripe persimmon.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Aged four, maybe five, was young Meg
When an older boy asked for a gleg —
A quick look — at her bum.
She refused. Sucked her thumb.
All he glimpsed was the top of her leg.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
They are dead, our white pines — so unjust!
It's that fungal blight, blistering rust.
Cronartium spores
Spawn on currants and cause
This dread spread to our trees. We are bust.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
They were born, just like us, from a womb,
And like us, they became bride and groom;
But the king and his queenie
In ancient Mycenae
Wound up in a beehive-style tomb.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Are you bound for a barrow to rot?
Better mention it now if you're not.
We had sort of inferred
You'd be shortly interred
In your outstanding burial plot.

limerick_list.author: GalFisk
limerick_list.text:
My projector's of type DLP,
With a chip inside called DMD:
It has mirrors on stilts
By the millions, with tilts.
They make bright and dark pixels, you see.

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
In the square in the center of town
Stood the tree in her snow-spangled gown.
High atop perched a star
To be seen from afar,
As a radiant beacon and crown.

limerick_list.author: Bob Dvorak
limerick_list.text:
We sat at the campfire, in turn
Making comments on what we might learn.
With a penchant for fustian,
She called it combustion,
While I said, "We're watching it burn."

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Can you fault me for canning their asses?
He's stupid; she's slow as molasses.
You expect, what? Some sorrow?
I'll forget them tomorrow,
Leaving only a stench—but that passes.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Stick 'em up! Gimme money! says you.
You mean OR? I don't know what to do!
You insist on a function —
Exclusive disjunction?
You know that I can't do the two.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Avocado hand—what can that mean?
Are your fingers all turning dark green?
No, it's caused, I submit,
By a knife and a pit
When your hand somehow gets in between.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Though Buffy, who hopped down the road,
Liked to stop at my humble abode,
She was hard to convince
I'm an actual prince,
And complained that I tasted like toad.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
There were Baxter and Redford and Ladd,
Seasoned actors who starred as this cad.
But suave Leo was best
And portrayed him with zest.
His great Gatsby drove movie fans mad.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"Simplistic!" declared the romantic,
And this word drove the classicist frantic.
"My preference, stylistic
Remains classicistic;
My featherbrained friend, you're pedantic!"

limerick_list.author: Brent Annable
limerick_list.text:
Blithe 12: mathematical fun!
Numbered counters (from 12 down to 1)
In three circles laid out,
And then jumbled about.
Once you've put them all back, then it's done!

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
One fs, femtosecond, is small;
It's so tiny, it's not long at all.
This truth I elicit:
Don't blink or you'll miss it
Since light barely moves at its call.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
With your mouse, move the burger in ways
That allow it to conquer the maze.
It's an advergame, Lou,
But then who's playing who
When, all through it, their jingle it plays?

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
The Lone Ranger peered over the brow
Of the cliff, and when Tonto asked, "How?"
Said, "I should've yelled whoa!
But the canyon below...
Well, it's all argentiferous now."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Put the blade that you once used to mow
On an L-bar of iron, then go
Get a handle of wood:
Make a council tool—good
In the field as a rake and a hoe.

limerick_list.author: Paperdragon
limerick_list.text:
Definitions are sometimes elastic.
My "card", for example, is plastic.
I use it and get
Into high-interest debt
And the banks call it "credit"! Fantastic!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
This affliction's ecdemic, no doubt:
It comes into our state from without.
With its wheezes and sneezes,
This evil disease is
Egregious, and taxing to rout.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Any fan who's been watching the trends
Of the Oscars, this year comprehends
That a comedy won't
Win Best Picture, but don't
Count them out. Who will win? That depends.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Manning triremes in old Roman wars
Were synched rowers in three banks of oars.
Triple tiers produced speed;
They were fearsome, indeed,
When they loomed off an enemy's shores.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
The shepherd said, "Each woolly tup
Must be shorn; only then can I sup
And relax with a beer."
It's sheer boredom to shear;
I'm so sick of this job—I'm fed up!

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
"You're a hairy, ill-mannered buffoon.
I'd suggest you try changing your tune."
"Your candor's impressive.
I may seem excessive,
But my bearishness makes women swoon."

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
Want to keep all the bad guys locked out
But let your staff in? There's no doubt
That a firewall's the thing
That will take out the sting
Of that menacing cyberpunk lout.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
Buy the farm means the end of the story.
It's when death comes on, all grim and gory.
The bell tolls for you
'Cause you're just passing through.
Take care, friend — memento <gulp> mori.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
He was brave, he was haughty. No bolder man
Held court in the county, no colder man.
(See his lip — watch it curl.)
Though today we'd say "earl",
Anglo-Saxon folk called him an "ealdorman".

limerick_list.author: Meg Beagle
limerick_list.text:
I'm a victim of boundless ambition.
I'm reaching the point of contrition.
Should I be head of state
With a suitable mate?
My desires could use some attrition.

limerick_list.author: R. A. Shortfellow
limerick_list.text:
A badinkadink: small and cute booty.
And I don't mean to sound like I'm snooty,
But I often prefer
A badonkadonk, sir.
(It's a larger one.)  Rooty-toot-tooty!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I thank God for my cool fidget spinner.
As a stress-relief aid, it's a winner.
With its lobes and ball-bearing
Smooth movement, it's sparing
Me anxiousness waiting for dinner.

limerick_list.author: Frank Luke
limerick_list.text:
We can bounce, have a ball with that toy,
And we dandle a  bouncing  babe boy.
"Jersey Bounce", a jounced tune,
Can be a jived croon.
Did your paycheck just   bounce  on you? Oy!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"To bump off is to hit or to whack,"
Said the Mafia don. "We've the knack.
For a payoff that's hefty,
We'll rub out Big Lefty—
Want him shot in the head or the back?"

limerick_list.author: bob killian
limerick_list.text:
Social contract's a fabric to knit
All the country together. So it
Causes great consternation
That grim dilaniation
Is shredding the cloth bit by bit.

limerick_list.author: John Young
limerick_list.text:
Dick put on a wig and some lipstick.
His dress made him look quite a hip chick.
At the drag race the guys
Stared at Dick in surprise,
Since the race was for cars—what a dipstick.

limerick_list.author: David
limerick_list.text:
His muscles could even make muscles,
The bloodless, cold strongman of Brussels.
Yet I'm sorry to say
That he faded away —
His corpuscles could not make corpuscles.

limerick_list.author: mrsrev
limerick_list.text:
Watch out, Daniel! There's lions about!
Faithful Daniel did not cry or shout.
He did not fear. Instead,
He, in prayer, bowed his head,
And the Lord made sure Daniel got out!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Jim's forlorn. Although nobody hates him,
No night of wild passion awaits him.
He's a slovenly lout
Fraught with maggots throughout,
So his grubbiness means no one dates him.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Sir John Falstaff led Prince Hal astray,
Was a coward and cheat — but, I pray,
On this man don't be hard;
'Twas the pen of the Bard
That had writ him thus, all in fair play.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
That shark has a stark, brilliant hue.
In a wreck, it endangers the crew.
It is found the world 'round,
Far from shore, and renowned
As a man-eater, known as great blue.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Caring not that he's spreading diseases,
Jude sprays us whenever he sneezes.
He'll spatter our food
On its platter—Jude's rude!
He is conscienceless—does what he pleases!

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
To the lady next door, I said: "Howdy!"
Was she chic?  My impression is cloudy.
Was her wardrobe, well, fab?
Was she dowdy, like, drab?
Hell, she wore an abayah; she's Saudi.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"Where's  my dress shirt? I want to get dressed."
"See the dry wash piled up on the chest?
It is terribly wrinkled.
Find your shirt, get it sprinkled,
Then see that it's properly pressed."

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
An em-dash can often replace
A parenthesis, bracket, or brace.
So you could—if you chose—
Have those symbols en-close
An aside in these dashes' em-brace.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The lions portrayed eye to eye
With their farthermost forepaws held high
On the enemy's coat
And escutcheon denote
(I ain't lyin') we're all gonna die.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Pastor Dan is firm denominationalist.
And the group that he leads? Congregationalist.
Every Sunday he's viewed
Holding services nude,
Since he's always been quite the sensationalist.

limerick_list.author: Goldie
limerick_list.text:
A quadrillionth's a very small jot —
Millionth-billionth, and that's not a lot.
The first half of a word,
Prefix femto- is heard
If in science you're properly taught.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
At checkouts, we pay for the food
In our carts, but self-checkouts exclude
The cashiers, and instead
Cards or money is fed
Through machines after bar codes are viewed.

limerick_list.author: psheil
limerick_list.text:
Far away from the big city's lights,
In the dark, there's a sight that excites;
When it's cloudless and clear
Even faint stars appear—
A whole panoply lights up the nights.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
In the good old days, life, in the main,
Was more simple and wholesome.  Our brain,
At least, tells us that's true.
There's a rosy rear view
When we're tripping down memory lane.

limerick_list.author: Jeff Foster
limerick_list.text:
If you've ever had reason to wonder
What they use to chart lightning and thunder,
A ceraunograph's it.
(I've fulfilled, I submit,
The unique obligation I'm under.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A fine dinner for twenty demands
You make flatware a part of your plans.
I forgot. Came the night,
Though the food was just right,
We ate duck à l'orange with our hands.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
Anacostia's Bladensburg docks
Host the black-crowned night heron, whose "quocks"
Summon fish in the gloaming;
It lurks, never roaming.
It lunges, suspending its vox.

limerick_list.author: matthewg and Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
When I try for a sport, running track,
I get nixed 'cause of skills that I lack.
"But Daffy," Coach begs,
"You've webbed feet and short legs!"
"That's damned ableism!" I quack.

limerick_list.author: sallycello
limerick_list.text:
I'm a renegade, not to be led;
Every rule and restriction I'll shed.
Antiformalist, I'll
Create my own style,
And be a free spirit instead.

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
I thought orienteering was crap;
I was right, and I'm now in a flap.
With some tor I've a tryst
On this moor, in the mist…
I deperditely glare at my map.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Most males like to air masculinity,
And most females display femininity.
There are some, though, I've seen
Who appear in-between
And whose gender bespeaks androgynity.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
In the twilight, he started to pray
For more daytime to finish a fray:
"Sun o'er Gibeon, STALL!
Moon o'er Ajalon, CRAWL!"
Captain Joshua's prayer saved the day.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
I'm exhausted; I'll shortly repair
To my yurt, or what some call a ger.
It's a round, spacious tent
That I bought in Tashkent.
All the comforts of home you'll find there.

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
At the start of Calamity Jane,
A stagecoach rolls in o'er the plain.
